lexUnit.name: flee.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: run away while being pursued

sentence.text: Barbarossa sent a mandate requiring Milan to give up her claims , but the Milanese consuls tore up the document , and the imperial ambassador fled an enraged crowd .
Thence it was finally brought to India in the thirteenth century by refugees fleeing Genghis Khan -- at about the same time as Abelard was lecturing to his students at the new university of Paris .
In Northern Iraq over a hundred thousand Kurdish children are still unable to return to their homes after being forced to flee Saddam Hussein 's army .
` We 're fleeing the beasts from the mountains .
Forced to flee the Nazis in 1937 -- leaving behind the 20,000 bibliography volumes -- the older Breslauer resettled his family in London but was killed shortly after in an air-raid .

Armies of monkeys marching through the jungle roof on swinging arms took fright , too , when they saw the little file of humans and they fled chattering through the upper branches almost as speedily as the birds .
They have been padlocked by owners fleeing militant kidnappings , extortions and crackdowns by the security forces .
Only the faded sashes they wore , and the weapons they carried , marked them as anything but ordinary folk fleeing the marauders .
The aged Duke Hunold was defeated , and fled to take refuge with Lupus , Duke of the Gascons .
Also , most prey can only flee fast in a forward direction , so attacking the head is the best way of hampering their escape .
It may have inundated lower Egypt , flooded the Nile and swept back the Red Sea waters to permit the escape of the Israelites fleeing from the Pharaoh .
A MAN was shot twice yesterday as he fled from five masked youths .
He was caught in a massive police hunt launched after the four fled through a hole in a fence around the jail playing field .
Mayer fled through the lobby and then , mustering all his courage , he turned and called Chaplin , who was in hot pursuit , a pervert .
